title: Angular 6/Angular CLI Upgrade Notes
text:
Angular 6/Angular CLI Upgrade Notes

Applies to the 4.9+ branch.

title: Redis setup for Docketing PortalHow to install and configure Redis for Docketing Portal NOTES:Other possible ways to install redis service
text:
How to install and configure Redis for Docketing Portal 

 

Installation steps

  • Download .msi redis for Windows from https://github.com/MicrosoftArchive/redis/releases
  • Install redis. Use default settings. For example default redis port is 6379;
  • Take the following config files from "IPMS.IPM.Core.Caching.Redis" project: "redis-ipms.conf", "redis.windows-service.conf". You can find "IPMS.IPM.Core.Caching.Redis" project folder in docketing-portal git repository.
  • Copy configuration files to a folder where Redis is installed. By default, the folder is "C:\Program Files\Redis". It will override default configuration file "redis.windows-service.conf";
  • Restart Redis Windows service after copying config files. Changes from configuration files are applied only after redis service restart.
    By default, Redis server runs as a Windows service. You can find it in the service list as "Redis" (Administrative Tools -> Services or Run -> services.msc).

Configuration files:

All config files provided below should be copied to the redis folder and applied as default configs.

  • redis.windows-service.conf - docketing portal redis configuration file that includes "redis-ipms.conf" config to override default settings.
  • redis-ipms.conf - specific settings for IPMS redis needs. All redis config modifications are specified here.

 

 

 

 

 

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

NOTES:

 

DO NOT USE IT FOR INSTALLATION PROCESS

Other possible ways to install redis service 

Currently, redis installation is not part of the deployment pipeline, so its installation process might be changed in the future.
Here are some alternative ways that can be considered.

Use redis nuget package 

Nuget package: https://www.nuget.org/packages/Redis-64/. All required redis files will be added to default nuget tools directory. Next required steps will be configuration and redis windows service run.

Redis installation using redis-server.exe 

Redis-server.exe usage: It is possible to install redis windows using redis-server.exe. Its usage is documented in "Windows Service Documentation.docx" file, which is part of redis program folder.
Service creation example:

  • installation: redis-server --service-install redis.windows-service.conf --service-name ipmsRedis --port 1234
  • run: --service-start --service-name ipmsRedis

This installation more flexible, but also more complex and therefore needs further research.

title: IPMS.UserManagement for Automation Testing
text:
IPMS.UserManagement API

This API was created for Automation Testing purposes. It has the following functionality:

  1. Creating/Updating/Deleting Users
    • Assigning them to Client Codes
    • Assigning them to Content Groups
    • Assigning them to Parties
  2. Creating/Updating/Deleting Content Groups
    • Assigning them to Client Codes
    • Assigning System Resources to them
    • Assigning Permissions to them
    • Assigning Application Security to them
    • Assigning Users to them

 

API repository: https://git.clarivate.io/projects/IPMS/repos/docketing-portal/browse/IPMS.UserManagement 

API url: http://ipms-webdev2.vm.com/IPMS.UserManagement/

API documentation (Swagger) url: http://ipms-webdev2.vm.com/IPMS.UserManagement/swagger/

 

API uses basic auth. Here are the credentials:

Login: IPManager

Password: 1PM@nagerAQA

These values are stored in AppSettings.config and can be changed.

 

When a user is created s/he is assigned a default password: ThomsonIPManager@1234

This value is stored encrypted in AppSettings.config file, and can be changed there as well.

 

Architecture:

 

Users:

 

 

 

 

Content Groups:


Aliaksandr Naryzhny

title: Docketing Portal Notifications Design
text:
Docketing Portal Notifications Design

This includes the notifications service, notifications bootstrapping, and an overview of some existing notifications use cases.

title: Admin Lockout with Notifications: High Level Design
text:
Admin Lockout with Notifications: High Level Design

 

*Note: Database polling may be replaced with direct integration into the Silverlight application in the future. In this case, initiation and cancellation handling will occur as a direct result of lockout initiation or cancellation, and notifications will be published directly from the Silverlight application. Most aspects will otherwise be the same.

title: IPDP - Environment issues QAs affected
text:
DateEnvironment issues descriptionStories delivery affectedRoot CauseTime QAs were blocked.
6 Sept 2018Queries on Docketing Portal are not accessible. 500 error is displayed in Console.The majority of stories are affected.

Hi All,

I commented out spGetMessageCenterUserResources stored procedure code on S5PP47 database.

It seems that queries are working fine now.

@SaiKrishna,
Can you please take a look why the stored procedure is failing (see the logs file from the server attached) and fix it?

@Keshav,
Message Center stories that rely on this SP may not work for S5PP client.

Best regards,
Dzmitry Karnitski

3 hours
12 Sept 2018 

The first column doesn’t contain values and cannot be accessible for all queries with “Data Modification Applicable” checkbox selected, e.g. “Docket Number” column on “PA All Cases”.

The majority of stories are affected.

From Vamshi:

 

Can you test this in the new build. it should be working as expected. 

let me know !

3 hours
13 Sept 2018

Blockers for QA -- Issues with Save/Save and Validate. 

1) All child tables from all iptypes come on DEF with IpType=1. That’s why save doesn’t work for all iptypes except patents. The defect number is https://jira.clarivate.io/browse/IPDP-2909.

2) ‘Save and Validate’ doesn’t work – get 500 error in response. Please see details in https://jira.clarivate.io/browse/IPDP-2921. This blocks acceptance at least of IPDP-1702 and IPDP-1832.

The majority of stories are affected.

1. I’ve did a quick investigation and seems like we have hardcoded IpType = 1 for Child Data Retrieving.

 

2. The issue #2 reproduced today again.

Because of it Save & Validate functionality does not work on S5PP client.

Save & Validate fails with a bunch of different errors related to transactions.

I propose QA’s to switch to E2PP client because S5PP client is highly unstable and from development side we don’t have any ways to fix this quickly.
Also, we cannot guarantee that after switching to E2PP client the issue won’t be reproduced there.

Issue#1 - reproduced from time to time within a half of a day.

Issue # 2 - still reproduced

14 Sept 2018

The story https://jira.clarivate.io/browse/IPDP-1314  was broken before demo.

https://jira.clarivate.io/browse/IPDP-1314 Resolved. 

The story was demonstrated on Monday before Commitment only.

18 Sept 2018

QA environment is not accessible.

The stories is Resolved state are affected - 4.undefinedThe whole day. 
21 Sept 2018

S5PP client is not working.

Automation demo is affected. DB issues5 hours

title: Docketing Portal - Code Review Guideline
text:
The document contains about review process at the Docketing Portal project.

 

Code review goals

 

  • To spot and fix defects early in the process thus reducing rework;
  • Better-shared understanding of the code base as team members learn from each other;
  • Helps to maintain a level of consistency in design and implementation;
  • Builds confidence of stakeholders (Jose T., Sricharan K.) about technical quality of the execution;
  • A different perspective. “Another set of eyes” adds objectivity;
  • Pride/reward. Recognition of coding prowess is a significant reward for many programmers;
  • Team cohesiveness. Working together helps draw team members closer.

 

Reviewer focus areas

 

  • General Unit Testing;
  • Comment and Coding Conventions (.Net );
  • Error Handling;
  • Resource Leaks;
  • Thread Safety;
  • Control Structures;
  • Performance;
  • Functionality;
  • Security.

 

Tips & Rules for the Developer

 

  • primary reviewer is the author – he should review the changes before sending it to code review;
  • entire point of a review is to find problems, don’t take it personally when one is uncovered;
  • understand and accept that you will make mistakes;
  • seek and accept input from others, especially when you think it’s not needed;
  • don’t rewrite code without consultation;
  • look at each change to your requirements, platform, or tool as a new challenge, not as some serious inconvenience to be fought;
  • understand that sometimes your ideas will be overruled;
  • review meetings are NOT problem solving meetings;
  • create small reviews;
  • split refactoring from new functionality.

 

Tips & Rules for the Reviewer

 

  • Critique code instead of people;
  • The only true authority stems from knowledge, not from position (do not force any commits if there are meaningful comments should be fixed, the only authority is common rules discussed and approved within team);
  • Review meetings are NOT problem solving meetings;
  • Ask questions rather than make statements;
  • Remember to praise;
  • Remember that there is often more than one way to approach a solution;
  • You shouldn’t rush through a code review - but also, you need to do it promptly;
  • Review fewer than 300-500 lines of code at a time.

 

 

Code review strategies

 

Current strategy

StrategyReviewersDescription

Review contract

Can be allDevelopers agrees to review each other. Strategy has some drawbacks, because usually developers tend to work in pairs. Can work well in self organized teams.

Help yourself

Can be allDeveloper looks for reviewer by his own. Can work well in self organized teams.

 

Pros

  • Easier to find reviewer;
  • Review on demand;
  • All team members are able to participate.

Cons

  • Work in pairs;
  • No guarantee in review quality;
  • Depends on self-organization of developer;
  • Quality gate is highly dependent on developer choice;
  • Risks of incorrect decision made is higher.

 

 

Proposed

StrategyReviewersDescription

Control center

Limited amount of peopleReview board is created which is consisted only of experienced developers. Reviews are only approved by them, which allows to keep quality on a good level. Tech Group decides how many approves are required for Merge Request, but more folks still able to contribute.

 

Pros

  • Review quality is proven by committee;
  • Experts provide independent feedback could be discussed in group;
  • Alternative points of view;
  • Can be reviewed by any of group members;
  • Scalable (by including more experts).

Cons

  • Can appear to be a bottleneck, BUT only if experts do not have regular sync-ups;
  • Continuous workload for experts.

 

 

Common rules

 

Code Review Roles

  1. Author – team member that provides code for code review;
  2. Reviewer – team member that performs code review and provides meaningful feedback to Author;
  3. Mediator – team member that is able to make a decision (expert of Merge Review Group, proven by implemented high-quality code in 10+ merge requests to the target repository) if any conflict cases arise between Author and Reviewer.

      

      Note: high-quality code means:

            1. PR’s with not more than ten major comments to be solved;

            2. Only code written from scratch is counted as high quality (not copy&pasted).

 

Code Review Requirements

  1. At least 1 Reviewer must be requested to perform a review (second and more are optional, but we should respect any meaningful comment from other experts);
  2. Requesting a Mediator presence is mandatory for each Code Review session;
  3. Amount of code provided for code review should not exceeds 500 LoC or should not affect more that 20 files (excluding auto-generated files).

    Note: any exceptional cases can be discussed with Mediator.

 

Code Review Procedure Flow

  1. Reaching Code Review conditions – assign your ticket in JIRA to Mediator with Code Review state;
  2. Mediator mentions all requested Reviewers in ticket comments;
  3. Use git GUI (whatever) functional to participate in discussions;
  4. After ending Code Review session – assign JIRA ticket to Author with On Review state;
  5. As a Author – after reviewing Code Review results uses Not Verified transition with respective comment if changes required or work is not finished;
  6. Author sets Verified status if all the comments from Reviewers were resolved and notifies Mediator;
  7. After verification Mediator should assign ticket back to Author in On Review state with Ready for merge comment.

 

      Note: Jira ticket templates must be tweaked to provide defined level of visibility regarding code review flow.

 

 

Additional tips

  • Use Markdown when possible;
  • Put meaningful description for PR changes descriptions;
  • Put story link (reference) into description of PR to simplify navigation;
  • Put PR reference in story\task comments to let it be easily trackable;
  • Use PR template upon PR creation (please see PR Template section);

 

PR Template

  • # Link (to issue number):

         Include the issue number here. This helps us to keep the information linked together.

  • # Summary (of the issue):

         A quick summary of the problem you are trying to solve.

  • # Description (of how this pull request fixes the issue):

         Include a quick discussion of how this change addresses the issue.

         Please also include any links or external information you may have used in order to address the issue.

  • # Testing performed:
     How have you tested to ensure that your change works as intended?
  • # Known issues (with pull request):

         Are there any known issues or downsides of this approach.

title: Export Query Results design

title: Client Side Display ConfigurationDesignUsagePending technical improvements
text:
Design

Here is the current design for static labels Display Configuration infrastructure on client-side:

 

 

Database relations and table connected to static labels Display Config are next:

   , where tables in blue were created and other were present before. Additional tables (not shown) include MESSAGES and MessageDomain, which are similar to the WIDGETS and WidgetDomain tables in function.


Usage

Basically to include Display Configuration next must be done:

Database

  1. Required labels or messages should be located in dbo.WIDGETS table or dbo.MESSAGES table
  2. Required domain should be created (if not present yet) in table dbo.DisplayConfigurationDomains
    Domain name must be descriptive and concrete. It should not contain dots inside.
    Domain (if possible) should be called after page, on which it is used, or part of page (if this part is shared between different pages).
  3. Mapping between required WIDGETS and Domain should be added to dbo.WidgetDomain and mapping between required MESSAGES and Domain should be added to dbo.MessageDomain. Both tooltip and primary display configuration values will be made available for any widgets or messages that are mapped.

Client-side

  • Add DisplayConfigurationModule.forChild() call with array of required domains to imports of some module. This will make display configured labels for this domains to load at module initialization.
  • To display a display-configured label for an item with name "label", type "type" (corresponding to a widget, a widget tooltip, a message, or a message tooltip), and domain "domain" you could:
    • Use the pipe "displayConfiguration" in a template. This will look like "domain.label" | displayConfiguration:'type' where "type" is a string that identifies the type of the display configured item. All valid type strings are available as constants in the DisplayConfigurationTypes class, and it is strongly suggested that these constants be used in place of string literals. Use of the next method (convenience pipes) is recommended over this method.
    • Use one of the convenience pipes: "widgetDisplayConfiguration", "widgetTooltipDisplayConfiguration", "messageDisplayConfiguration", or "messageTooltipDisplayConfiguration". These pipes behave nearly identically to the "displayConfiguration" pipe, but they do not require a type parameter: each pipe automatically applies the type that is included in its name. Use of one of these pipes will look like "domain.label" | widgetDisplayConfiguration
    • Inject the service "BaseDisplayConfigurationService" into a component. Then the component will have some code like displayConfigurationService.getTranslation("domain", "type", "label")
    • In case you have display configured string containing placeholders like {0}, {1} and so on you can provide params for interpolation
      "domain.label" | widgetDisplayConfiguration:"param0":"param1" will output "param0-param1", where initial translation was "{0}-{1}"
      Parameters interpolated positionally starting from 0

Access to Display Configuration classes must be gained using \src\infrastructure\display-configuration\index.ts

Nothing additionally should be added to "providers" of component or module. All providing must be withing DisplayConfigurationModule if you aren't overriding default display configuration classes

Import of DisplayConfigurationModule.forChild() call must not appear in module already imported DisplayConfigurationModule.forChild()

 

In case you need some reference you could see how this implemented inside footer component (src/app/layout/footer)

 

Pending technical improvements

  • IPDP-988: Allow nested calls of DisplayConfigurationModule.forChild()

title: IPMS.IPManager.Server ( save&validate )
text:
Preface

Docketing Portal has to support a save&validate functionality according to https://jira.clarivate.io/browse/IPDP-541 story.

The IPMS.IPManager.Server nuget package already contains necessary validation functionality.



Challenge

Docketing portal and IPMS.IPManager.Server use different versions unity package, so as result there is problem with unity containers interaction. 

 

Solution

  • Place necessary assembly in bin folder and specifie where the common language runtime (CLR) can find them using <codeBase>
  • Set up binding redirect attributes
  • We have to use <PreBuildEvent> for production environment.

 

Picture below describes interaction with IPMS.IPManger.Server.

title: Upgrade Database Scripts folder
text:
We have a special solution folder where you can store all necessary SQL scripts to update/create tables in the existing database.

 

All scripts you can find at $pathToSolution/Solution Items/UpgradeDatabaseScripts folder:

 

 

The script name template:  V{orderNumber}_ScriptDescription.sql  (you can see several examples on the picture above)

title: Front-End Coding Guidelines
text:
Basic application structure

- src - source code of Idea Portal application

   - app - modules and code which are related to the application.

         - app-config - configuration of the application

         - home - home module (Represent home page with a dashboard)

         - layout - layout module (Represent layout page header, footer, nav-bar). This is Startup component.

         - shared - components/modules which should be shared across all application.

               

               - state - all modules which are responsible for application state management should be placed here.

               - constants - constants which should be shared across all application.

               - components - components which are specific for the current application but should not be shared across multiple applications.

               - directives - common directives.

               - pipes - shared pipes for unified formatting.

               - services - reusable services.

               - tests - shared mocks and stubs.

               - interceptors - requests interceptors for custom request handling implementation.  

   - controls - reusable controls. This controls can be reused across application (Framework level). One control - one module.

         - dashboard - reusable Angular based components which can be moved to global toolkit in the future.

   - images - images which is used across apps.

   - fonts - fonts which is used across apps.

   - infrastructure - reusable modules which can be reused across multiple application (Framework level).

         - data-access - reusable data providers/ odata implementation (Example of reusable module).

 

Naming convention

- names should be meaningful and semantically correct.

 

Files/folder naming

- use kebab-case (decision-schedule, case-request-overview).

- use specific postfix separated by dot for identify role of class/file (decision-schedule.component.ts, shared-state.module.ts, decision-schedule.component.html, decision-schedule.component.scss, decimal.pipe, expand.decorator)

- use kebab-case for interfaces (decision-schedule-interface)

- use postfix .spec for unit tests (template: [file name].spec.ts   |  example: decision-instruction-action-creator.spec.ts)

 

Code elements naming

- use PascalCase for classes and interfaces. Ex: DecisionScheduleComponent, SomeAwersomeInterface.

- use 'Interface' postfix for interfaces. do not use 'I' prefix. Right way: SomeAwersomeInterface. Wrong way: ISomeAwersome.

- use camelCase for variables, methods, properties, fields, parameters.

- you can use PascalCase for naming of models properties which should be mapped to backend models to avoid complex mapping logic. 

- use PascalCase for constants.

- do NOT use abbreviations except cases when it is belong to domain specific language. Wrong: extrnCntrbtrs, Right: externalContributors. (IpmsUser is acceptable abbreviation)

 

Formatting

- follow tslint rules.

- insert blank line before constructor.

- insert blank line after method implementation.

- insert blank line after imports section.

- leave {} in the same line with module definition if module class is empty. Right: export class InventionsModule {}

- insert spaces for inline object creation. Wrong: {withCredentials: true}, Right: { withCredentials: true }

- do NOT insert blank line between imports.

- use cascade formatting for brackets:

Wrong:

Right:

- place dot in the new line if you have long chain of calls.

Wrong:

Right:

 

Toolkit usage

- import controls from toolkit pacakge root:

Wrong: import { TextboxModule } from '@ipms/textbox/textbox.module';

Right: import { TextboxModule } from '@ipms/textbox';

 

Code signature

- specify access modifiers for methods.

- specify types for input and output parameter of methods.

- use private readonly modifier for injected dependencies. 

- use const for variables which should not be changed.

- use readonly modifier for readonly fields.

- do NOT use redundant brackets for lambda function definition.

Wrong:

Right:

 

Common notes

- use async pipe if possible.

- use OnPush change detection is possible. (Some components can not work with OnPush mode. In this case you can leave a comment and remove OnPush change detection.)

- use lodash method in the application specific components if possible.

- use same style to assign injected properties in scope of one component

Right:

or

Wrong:

- place library imports first then application imports

Right:

Wrong:

- use _.defaults method to setup defaults values for model.

- use spread operator instead of _.merge, Object.assign, _.assign, array.concat when possible.

- preferable way to initialize arrays with empty value is: Clients: [] or Clients = [].

 

Observables best practices  

- implement unsubscribe logic if you manually subscribe to a observable.

- use Observables only from root of rxjs. import { Observable } from 'rxjs/Observable';

- use .distinctUntilChanged() method to avoid multiple same values propagation.

- to import rxjs operator, use default importing: import 'rxjs/add/operator/filter'

 

Redux

- do NOT mutate state in the store.

- start action names from prefix: Wrong: ADD_EXTERNAL_CONTRIBUTOR: 'ADD_EXTERNAL_CONTRIBUTOR' , Right: ADD_EXTERNAL_CONTRIBUTOR: 'EXTERNAL_CONTRIBUTOR_ADD_EXTERNAL_CONTRIBUTOR'

 

Code style guide

Basic guides

 

1. Angular: Style Guide - ts - GUIDE 

2. Typescript: Coding guidelines · Microsoft/TypeScript Wiki · GitHub

3. Documentation style: GitHub - TypeStrong/typedoc: Documentation generator for TypeScript projects. 

Tools (see tslint config):

TSLint - Typescript code style checker

https://palantir.github.io/tslint/GitHub - mgechev/codelyzer: Linting for Angular projects.

GitHub - TypeStrong/typedoc: Documentation generator for TypeScript projects.    

 

 

AoT  specific rules

 

Angular Docs

title: Docekting Portal - Data Entry Form rendering mechanism
text:
Preface

 

Docketing Portal supports a functionality to render dynamic Data Entry Forms based on configuration in database. This form is used to enter user data to IPManager/Docketing Portal for further processing and validation. As clients' machines can possibly not many resources, it makes sense to distribute the load between client-side and server-side applications.

 

Requirements

  • The number of controls can be up to 100+
  • It should render as fast as possible (even in IE)
  • It should support IPMS ToolKit controls set

 

Design

 

To see High Level Design Overview please check this document.

 

Code comments

 

Current approach is implemented using dynamic Angular view compilation. For this reasons, JitCompilerFactory was imported to DEF module:


 

All logic related to view compilation is encapsulated in DataEntryFormRenderingService. This service contains createDynamicComponent and createDynamicModule methods which are responsible for dynamic declaration of @NgModule and @Component.
After module and component are created, Angular compiles them inside of DataEntryFormRenderingService.compileDynamicModule method using Angular JIT compiler's compileModuleAndAllComponentsAsync method. As a result of compiling, compiler returns root component factory, which caches using IPMS caching framework (client-side) and then inserts into DOM container.
